questions.text: Which of the following cells act as touch receptors?
questions.solution:
Merkel cells act as touch receptors. 

Merkel cells located in the basal layer of the epidermis and outer root sheath of some big hair follicles function as follows:

  • They act as slowly adapting mechanoreceptors in the skin that convey touch sensation
  • They detect the directional deformation of the epidermis and hair movement
  • They also sense sustained pressure and edges of applied objects on the skin

questions.text: A 14-year-old male has been diagnosed with a condition due to a DNA repair gene defect. He is having hyperpigmentation on the skin and high risk for the development of skin cancers as per the physician. Which of the following mechanisms is likely to be defective in this condition?
questions.solution:
The above given clinical findings is suggestive of xeroderma pigmentosum. Xeroderma pigmentosum is an example of defective DNA nucleotide excision repair where there is an inability to repair DNA pyrimidine dimers caused by UV exposure.

Xeroderma Pigmentosum (XP) is a rare autosomal recessive genetic disorder characterized by defective DNA repair which leads to clinical and cellular hypersensitivity to ultraviolet radiation and other carcinogenic agents.  

Important clinical features are:

Intense cutaneous photosensitivity, xerosis, poikiloderma, actinic keratosis, acute burning under minimal sun exposure, erythemas, hyperpigmented lentiginous macules, and malignant lesions in sun-exposed areas, including basocellular carcinoma, squamous cell carcinoma, and melanoma.  

The final diagnosis of XP can be confirmed by special laboratory tests by examining the DNA damage repair in cells from cultures exposed to ultraviolet radiation. The most common tests are skin biopsy and culture of skin fibroblasts.  

There is no cure for XP. Treatment consists of minimizing exposure to sunlight and regular dermatological care, as well as surgery for recurrent tumors excision. Patients should be followed up every 3 months.

Genetic counseling is important in a family that has an affected child and is considering having more children.

questions.text: A child presented with history of ingestion of unknown plant and developed mydriasis, tachycardia, dry mouth, warm skin and delirium. Which of the following group of drugs is likely to be responsible for the symptoms of child ?
questions.solution:
Mydriasis, tachycardia, dry mouth, warm (hot) skin and delirium are classical symptoms of anticholinergic overdose. Anticholinergic is the more appropriate option here considering the classical symptoms following the ingestion of unknown plants that can more likely be containing belladonna alkaloids. Physostigmine is the drug of choice for the treatment of atropine and belladona poisoning.

Sympathomimetics can cause mydriasis and tachycardia. Delirium is rare and hyperthermia can be seen secondarily to increased agitation and aggressive moments. They are unlikely to present with dry mouth. But the answer can also be sympathomimetic as dry mouth cannot be a differentiating factor. (Option B)

Opioid overdose results in miosis and other symptoms are not suggestive of opioid overdose (Option C).

Benzodiazepine causes CNS depression and changes in pupil diameter are highly unlikely with its overdose (Option D).

questions.text: Identical twins have similarities in all except :
questions.solution:
Fingerprint pattern differs in identical twins.

The pattern of the fingerprint comprises arches, loops, whorls or combinations of these three patterns, this is unique to every individual and does not match even for identical twins.

questions.text: A patient complains that he feels like the room is spinning when he gets up from lying down or when he turns his head. He has no history of loss of consciousness. Which of the following could be the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Based on the symptoms the most probable diagnosis is Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo(BPPV).

  • BPPV is one of the common causes of recurrent vertigo and the episodes are brief (<1min) and are always provoked by changes in head position.
  • The attacks are caused by free-floating calcium carbonate crystals usually dislodged from the posterior canal.
  • Epleys maneuver is done to reposition the crystals into the macula from the semicircular canals.

questions.text: Which among the following ocular lesions are seen in gout?
questions.solution:
Ocular manifestations seen in gout are episcleritis, scleritis, and uveitis.

There is deposition of uric acid in the cornea, conjunctiva, and sclera.

Ocular structures have relatively poor solvent ability, in addition to lower temperatures, and therefore, they are predisposed to tophi deposition.

As a result of urate deposits, crystal-induced inflammation of the affected tissue is responsible for causing episcleritis, scleritis, and uveitis.

questions.text: Primaquine is contraindicated in______
questions.solution: Primaquine is contraindicated in pregnancy, infants and G6PD deficient patients.

questions.text: The syndromic management of urethral discharge includes the treatment of_______
questions.solution: Syndromic management of urethral discharge in males involves the treatment of gonorrhea and chlamydial infection.

questions.text: Which of the following vaccines is not included in the Intensified Mission Indradhanush Scheme?
questions.solution:
Typhoid vaccine is not a part of the Intensified Mission Indradhanush scheme. 

The Intensified Mission Indradhanush has been introduced to ensure full immunization (more than 90%) by December 2018. It now includes 12 vaccine preventable diseases (updated from the 7 VPDs that Mission Indradhanush focussed on). 4 rounds of immunisation are proposed to be held for 7 days each month (from the 7th-13th of each month). The diseases are:

  • TB
  • Polio
  • Hep B
  • Diphtheria
  • Pertusis
  • Tetanus
  • Measles

And included recently:

  • Rotavirus diarrhoea
  • Rubella (as MR vaccine)
  • H. influenzae B diseases (as part of the pentavalent vaccine)
  • Pneumococcal meningitis
  • Japanese Encephalitis

 

 

 

The purpose of Intensified Mission Indradhanush is to reach each and every child under 2 years of age and all those pregnant women who have been left uncovered under the routine immunization coverage. It has been launched by the Government of India in October 2017.

In february 2020, the government launched Intensified Mission Indradhanush (IMI). The aim is to reach out to partially vaccinated and unvaccinated children with all the available vaccines under Universal Immunization Program (UIP) across 381 districts in 29 States/UTs.

questions.text: What is the GCS of a patient with a head injury who opens her eyes in response to a loud voice, localizes pain, and is confused and disoriented?
questions.solution:
In this patient GCS is E3M5V4

Eye-opening to loud voice-3

Motor response localizes pain-5

 Verbal response is confused and disoriented-4

GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.

questions.text: A patient presented with a prolonged fever for 2 weeks and new-onset seizures. Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) obtained on admission showed a 1.5 cm vegetation on the tricuspid valve. Multiple painless skin lesions are present on the hands as shown in the image below. What are these lesions called?
questions.solution:
The skin lesions shown in the image are Janeway lesions. They are non-tender, erythematous or hemorrhagic macular or nodular lesions, which are present on the palms or soles.

Patients with infective endocarditis can have cardiac or non-cardiac manifestations.

Cardiac manifestations of IE:

  • Presence of new regurgitant murmurs
  • Congestive heart failure due to valve dysfunction
  • Perivalvular abscesses and intracardiac fistulae- This is caused due to the extension of infection beyond the valves and into the adjacent myocardial tissue
  • Conduction system defects- due to the damage of the interventricular septum by the abscess.
  • Embolization of coronary arteries

Noncardiac manifestations of IE are:

  • Arterial emboli- causing pain of ischemia of the organs
  • Osler's nodes-are painful, red, nodular lesions usually located in the pads of the fingers and toes
  • Roth's spots- retinal hemorrhages with a pale center
  • Janeway lesions- In contrast to Osler's nodes, these are faint, red, painless macules on palms and soles. They occur as a result of septic embolization and are commonly associated with staphylococcal IE.
  • Glomerulonephritis
  • Positivity for rheumatoid factor
  • Petechiae on oral and conjunctival mucosa
  • Splinter subungual haemorrhages-painless, dark red lines in the nailbed.
  • Mycotic aneurysms

Another skin finding that can be found in patients with infective endocarditis is Osler's node. In contrast to Janeway lesions, these are small, tender, red papules which are present on the distal finger and toe pads.

The image below depicts Roth's spots which are exudative lesions in the retina. This is an immunological phenomenon.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman came with complaints of headache for 1 month. She also reports aching of the jaw during her meals. Over the last week, she has experienced episodes of painless visual loss which lasts for around 10 minutes. Which will be the best investigation for the diagnosis of the given condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of giant cell arteritis. The best investigation for the diagnosis of giant cell arteritis is temporal artery biopsy.

Histopathology shows panarteritis with the presence of mononuclear cells and giant cells.

questions.text: An 18-year-old man presents to the clinic with a non-specific history of malaise. Mild sensorineural hearing loss had been diagnosed during his early education, although hearing aids were not required. He gives a history of recurrent hematuria and current investigations reveal the same. What is the most likely diagnosis among the following?
questions.solution:
Alport syndrome is the most likely diagnosis. Alport syndrome is a cause of recurrent hematuria, which is associated with sensorineural hearing loss.

 Other causes of recurrent hematuria

  • Alport syndrome
  • IgA nephropathy
  • Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD)
  • Papillary necrosis
  • Renal cell carcinoma

questions.text: In patients with confirmed sialolithiasis, what is the most common location of stone formation?
questions.solution:
The most common site for salivary gland stone formation is the submandibular gland due to highly viscous secretions. 

80% of submandibular stones are radio-opaque, while parotid duct stones are usually radiolucent and rarely visible on plain radiography. Parotid gland sialography is usually required to identify the stone. A stone located in the collecting duct or within the gland may be managed by either endoscopic retrieval or lithotripsy; in rare cases, surgical removal via a parotidectomy approach may be required.

 The below USG image shows a stone in the Wharton duct of the submandibular gland.

questions.text: In a patient with critical limb ischemia, what is the ankle-brachial pressure index (ABPI) likely to be?
questions.solution:
In a patient with critical limb ischemia, the ABPI is < 0.3.

Related Pearl: Ankle–brachial Pressure Index (ABPI)

The ankle-brachial Pressure Index (ABPI) is the ratio of systolic pressure at the ankle to that in the arm.

The numerator is the highest pressure in the dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial, or peroneal artery and the denominator is the highest brachial systolic pressure.

ABPI Reading Interpretation
>0.91 < 1.3 Normal
<0.9 Diagnostic of occlusive arterial disease in patients with symptoms of claudication or other signs of ischemia
0.5 to 0.9 Arterial obstruction often associated with claudication
<0.3 Critical limb ischemia (multilevel obstruction i.e any combination of iliac, femoral or tibial vessel disease and may be associated with non-healing ulcerations, ischemic rest pain, or pedal gangrene.
>1.4 Signifies poor compressibility of the arteries. Mostly due to calcification because of increased age, diabetes etc.

Note: A fall in the resting ABPI of more than 20% after exercise is indicative of arterial disease.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a history of greenish discharge from the nipple for the past 1 month. Personal history is significant for cigarette smoking. On compression of her breast, greenish discharge from multiple ducts was observed. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis of a patient with greenish discharge from multiple ducts is duct ectasia. 

Duct ectasia is the dilatation of breast ducts. It is the most common cause of nipple discharge in nonlactating women. This condition is associated with smoking and diabetes.

The initial stage of this disease consists of dilatation of one or more lactiferous ducts. These ducts get filled with stagnant brown or green colored secretions. In the later stages, the accumulation of fluid in the lactiferous ducts leads to infection and inflammation, causing periductal mastitis. The infections are most often mixed infections of aerobic and anaerobic flora of the skin.

Patients may present with nipple discharge, abscess, fistula or nipple retraction.

questions.text: Which of the following renal stones is not formed in acidic urine?
questions.solution:
Struvite stone is produced in alkaline urine, especially when urea-splitting proteus organisms are present.

  • Struvite is a triple-phosphate calculus (calcium phosphate often with ammonium magnesium phosphate), grossly smooth in texture, and dirty-white in color.
  • The calculus may enlarge to fill most of the collecting system, forming a stag-horn calculus.

questions.text: A pregnant woman complained of excessive vomiting and mild vaginal bleeding for 2 weeks at a period of gestation of 14 weeks. On examination, fundal height corresponds to 16 weeks and fetal heart sound is absent.  USG shows the presence of a snowstorm appearance. What is the management____
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of molar pregnancy and regardless of uterine size, molar evacuation by suction and curettage is usually the preferred treatment. 

With large moles, adequate anesthesia, sufficient intravenous access, and blood-banking support are imperative.

Intraoperative sonography is recommended to help ensure that the uterine cavity has been emptied.

Indication for hysterectomy in molar pregnancy:

  • Preferred for women who have completed their family.
  • In women >40 years, who are at high risk for GTN.

questions.text: A 36-year-old female patient was undergoing diagnostic dilatation and curettage. The instrument given below is used to expose the cervix prior to cervical dilatation. Identify the given instrument.
questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the image is Sims' speculum.

The Sims’ vaginal speculum with an anterior vaginal wall retractor can be used for examination of the cervix. This is used to expose the cervix prior to cervical dilatation. It is used for the assessment of the vaginal wall for cystocele and rectocele. 

Option B - Cusco's speculum is a bivalve self-retaining speculum, ideal for an office examination. It allows satisfactory inspection of the cervix, obtaining a Pap smear, and collection of the vaginal discharge from the posterior fornix. An image of Cusco's speculum is given below

Option C - Auvard speculum is a heavy retractor provided with a heavy metal ball and is self-retaining. It is used in vaginal hysterectomy to retract the posterior vaginal wall. A channel is provided in the handle to collect the blood and drain it. An image of the Auvard speculum is given below.

Doyen's retractor is used to retract the abdominal wall as well as the bladder to facilitate better exposure of the lower uterine segment during cesarian operation. It is also used to pull back the soft tissues to widen the surgical field during laparotomy.

The image below shows Doyen's retractor.

questions.text: Which of the following pathogens is responsible for the largest fraction of deaths due to gastroenteritis in children less than 5 years?
questions.solution:
Rotavirus is the most common identifiable viral cause of gastroenteritis in children. It accounts for 29% of deaths caused by diarrhea in children aged < 5 years.

  • Most common cause of bacterial diarrhea : Enterotoxigenic E.Coli 
  • Most common cause of dysentry : Shigella flexneri

questions.text: A throw ball player presents to the emergency room with pain over the shoulder, arm abducted and externally rotated and loss of sensation over the proximal lateral aspect of the arm. Which of the following nerve injuries is likely associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation is suggestive of anterior dislocation of shoulder. The most common nerve injured in these cases is the axillary nerve as it winds around the humerus.

In axillary nerve injury, there is loss of sensation over a small part of the deltoid region in upper arm (regimental badge area) and weakness in abduction (15-90 degress) due to denervation of deltoid. Overhead abduction is unaffected as it is the function of serratus anterior and trapezius muscles.

questions.text: The Money bag heart is seen in:
questions.solution:
The Money bag heart is seen in pericardial effusion.

Plain PA chest X-ray shows an enlarged cardiac silhouette. There is effacement of the normal cardiac borders, development of a ‘flask’ or ‘water bottle’ cardiac configuration and bilateral hilar overlay which are features of pericardial effusion. It is also known as Money bag or leather bottle-shaped heart.

Investigation of choice: Echocardiography.

Signs on plain radiograph include:

  • Globular enlargement of the cardiac shadow giving a water bottle configuration.
  • Lateral CXR may show a vertical opaque line (pericardial fluid) separating a vertical lucent line directly behind the sternum (paracardial fat) anteriorly from a similar lucent vertical lucent line (epicardial fat) posteriorly; this is known as the Oreo cookie sign.

questions.text: Dialectical behaviour therapy is used in the management of?
questions.solution:
Dialectical behaviour therapy (DBT) is used in the management of borderline personality disorder.

It is a form of psychotherapy, which is the treatment of choice in borderline personality disorder. DBT is used especially for those with parasuicidal behavior, such as frequent cutting.

Patients are seen weekly, to improve interpersonal skills and decrease self-destructive behavior using techniques involving advice, metaphor, storytelling, and confrontation.

Other modalities of treatment include:

  • Mentalization-based treatment.
  • Transference-focused psychotherapy.
  • Drugs – antipsychotics, antidepressants (SSRI, TCA), and mood-stabilizing drugs.

questions.text: The image shown below is the technique of insertion of?
questions.solution:
The image shown above is the technique of insertion of laryngeal mask airway.

Laryngeal mask airway (LMA) is a supraglottic airway device that is positioned in the hypopharynx.

Classic Laryngeal Mask Airway

Supraglottic airway devices are used with both spontaneously and ventilated patients during anesthesia.

LMA has advantages of being used in many settings, including the operating room (alternate route of ventilation), the emergency department (difficult intubation), and out-of-hospital care (paramedics). This is because it is easy to use, quick to place even for the inexperienced provider and has a very high success rate.

The technique of insertion:

  • The deflated cuff of LMA is lubricated and inserted blindly into the hypopharynx so that, once inflated, the cuff forms a low-pressure seal around the entrance to the larynx.
  • Correct placement of the tube is confirmed by giving gentle positive pressure ventilation while checking for chest rise and ETCO2 using capnography.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with flaccid bullae over the mucosa and skin and oral ulcers. Histopathology shows a suprabasal acantholytic blister with superficial dermal infiltration by lymphocytes, macrophages, and eosinophils. Direct immunofluorescence for immunoglobulin IgG is as seen below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Flaccid bullae, oral ulcers, suprabasal acantholytic blisters and fish net appearance on immunofluorescence are characteristic of Pemphigus vulgaris.

The above image shows deposition of immunoglobulin along the plasma membrane of keratinocytes in a reticular or fish net-like pattern accompanied by suprabasalar loss of cell-to-cell adhesion (acantholysis).

Pemphigus is a blistering disorder caused by autoantibodies that result in the dissolution of intercellular attachments within the epidermis and mucosal epithelium.

Variants:

(1) Pemphigus vulgaris

(2) pemphigus vegetans

(3) pemphigus foliaceus: Autoantibodies are against Dsg1 alone, leading to superficial, subcorneal blisters.

(4) pemphigus erythematosus

(5) paraneoplastic pemphigus: in association with various malignancies, most commonly non-Hodgkin lymphoma

Pemphigus vulgaris

  • Most common type of pemphigus
  • Involves the mucosa and skin
  • Autoantibodies against Desmoglein 1 and 3
  • Histology: Suprabasal acantholytic blister leaving behind single layer of intact basal cells: the row of tombstones appearance
  • Direct immunofluorescence: A fish net-like pattern of intercellular IgG deposits.

questions.text: Which of the following compounds are used in PET scan?
questions.solution:
PET involves the use of a radiolabelled bio compound - 2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG) which is injected intravenously. It is based on the principle that tumour cells have a high metabolic rate. FDG is metabolised to FDG-6-phosphate which cannot be further metabolised by tumour cells, and hence it accumulates and concentrates in tumour cells. This accumulation is detected and quantified.

Applications of PET :-

Oncologic:

  • Detection, staging, drug response
  • Differentiation between radiation necrosis and recurrence

 Neurologic:

  • Early diagnosis of Alzheimer's disease
  • Localisation of seizure focus in interictal phase
  • Localising eloquent areas (e.g. speech, motor function)

Cardiac: Identification of hibernating myocardium
